title: VA - California Cool (1993)
description:
LINER NOTES

Ever since Stan Kenton disbanded his Innovations Orchestra in Los Angeles in 1951, both the local jazz and movie colonies have co-existed comfortably along California's coastline.
Far from being beached, most of these ex-Kentonites, together with a number who'd previously been in Woody Herman's employ, soon found themselves leading a lucrative lifestyle that quickly translated into matching continental sports' cars and casual wear. For most of those who worked Hollywood's sound stages by day, also blew jazz by night at local clubs.
The commencement of Sunday afternoon jams at The Lighthouse on May 29 1949 and Shorty Rogers recording his Modern Sounds 10-inch for Capitol on October 8, 1951 are regarded as the two major events that signify what became universally refered to as the West Coast Scene. Long before that, jazz had been an intregral part of the area's local night life especially along Central Avenue (the Harlem of the West Coast) where Dexter Gordon was the key figure along with Warded Gray, Teddy Edwards, Sonny Criss and Hampton Hawes. A bustling locale crammed with clubs such as Billy Berg's, The Jungle Room and Jack's Basket that nightly presented jukebox stars of the calibre of Slim Gaillard, Charles Brown,
Louis Jordan and Nat Cole.
However, by the early 1950s, the indiginous music scene had, in the quest for the almighty dollar, polarized along race lines, and (white) West Coast Jazz was a commercial reality. It's bright primary coloured leisure image was meant to reflect an optimistic and affluent postwar mood of prosperity. Not for these guys the smoke and shadows of New York's jazz cellars. Out on the coast, the air was fresh, palm trees lined the avenues and the big decision of the day was whether to surf or golf!
Look closer and it was obvious that this was a surface image - albeit well intended. Likewise, listen closely to the wide cross section of music contained herein and it's obvious that, from Mulligan and Pepper right through to Edwards and Criss, there's much more depth than the whole movement was first credited with.

09. Gloria Woods With Pete Candoli - Hey Bellboy    [2:48]
10. Art Pepper With Shorty Rogers Nine - Diablo's dance    [3:23]
11. Teddy Edwards With Les McCann Ltd - Our Love Is Here To Stay    [5:51]
12. Bobby Troup - Route 66    [2:38]
13. Bob Gordon With Jack Montrose - Two Can Play    [2:27]
14. Bud Shank - Take 5    [2:27]
15. Chet Baker With Bud Shank Orchestra - Jimmy's Theme    [2:51]
16. June Christy - Something Cool    [4:18]
17. Art Pepper Quartet - Mambo De La Pinta    [4:15]
18. Peggy Lee With George Shearing - Do I Love You    [3:46]
19. Curtis Amy With Dupree Bolton - Katanga    [3:04]
20. Serge Chaloff - Handful Of Stars    [5:37]
21. Sonny Criss - West Coast Blues    [4:59]



Compiled and annotated by Ray Carr (Vox Magazine).

This Compilation was inspired by the books "California Cool" (Graham Marsh & Glyn Callingham ed) and by Roy Carr's "The Hip". 
Also by the essential NME cassette "Low Lights & Trick Mirrors"

...Special thanks to Glyn for 'Mambo' & Roy for the entire concept.
